author: ds580
body:
I did some research and like them. They appear to solve the lidar cost challenges which puts them in a good position for automotive (lidar has inherent advantages over stereo camera systems that are common today for cost efficiency). This is a good startup with a very specific and focused problem to solve.
The even more enticing prospect to me are the consumer electronics applications. IPhone 12 now added lidar to improve photo depth. That's just the beginning of usage for these. With a simple cost effective chip these could start showing up a lot of places.
What isn't clear to me is how they are protecting this tech and preventing others from replicating unless it's strictly cost advantage of being first.

Take a look through the investor pitch from Aeva. It has good info and makes it digestible.

author: Adderalin
body:
$65/hr is also relative to how much you invest. For the $90k difference in the two assets over 2 years at 21.5% annualized and 25% annualized the starting bucket for SPY and the active trading would be 1,050,000.00 each. 

If OP did $2.1m in each bucket then it'd be $180k difference and so on. 

Now if OP just threw his entire $2,100,000 starting capital into a more efficient portfolio like [UPRO/TMF](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio?s=y&timePeriod=2&startYear=2018&firstMonth=1&endYear=2020&lastMonth=11&calendarAligned=true&includeYTD=false&initialAmount=2100000&annualOperation=0&annualAdjustment=0&inflationAdjusted=true&annualPercentage=0.0&frequency=4&rebalanceType=3&absoluteDeviation=5.0&relativeDeviation=25.0&showYield=false&reinvestDividends=true&portfolioNames=false&portfolioName1=Portfolio+1&portfolioName2=Portfolio+2&portfolioName3=Portfolio+3&symbol1=UPRO&allocation1_1=55&symbol2=TMF&allocation2_1=45) he'd be up to a total of 4,920,310 for a gain of $2,820,310 for 0 hours of work.

author: DoubleKillGG
body:
Your source is a seekingalpha article. Not only that, your source backs up my point. 

Yes, there are around 20% shares floating in the market. How? Thiel, Karp, et al., sold them to the market to make shares available. Why? In a direct listing no new shares are created. Before they sold there was 0% shares floating in the market but by selling shares they made it available to be traded on the market. 

Why does your source reference an article that states that after a lock-up ends that there could be a flood of "new" shares if those subject to the lock-up decide to sell? \[*Keep in mind that "new" means shares that were not previously allowed to be traded on the market but are now allowed to.*\] It's because when they sell they increase the %float of shares trading in the market. Sounds familiar? Let's say, for example, the float increase 5%. How? No new shares were created? How did the float increase by 5%? Because early investors sold their shares to their market making previously unavailable shares available.

Congrats buddy, you played yourself.

author: Pyrrhura_molinae
body: I read this sub for entertainment only. So many people here are not understanding that short term capital gains are taxed at whatever your marginal tax rate state/fed. I am in Oregon, with a 9.9% income tax rate, plus a higher marginal Federal tax rate. If I am not taking that into account for risk management, all I am doing is putting in a lot of effort for a lot of risk for modest after tax gains which is why I am mostly now dealing with long term investing which has a much lower tax rate, and much less stress. I assume many of you enjoy this like it is Vegas. I don't.

author: visionridge
body:
One more thing I would like to add. The concept of a Black Swan which is simply an event that is unlikely or hard to quantify that can still occur that has an immeasurable but extremely large downward or negative impact. Everyone seems to believe SPACs are in a bubble right now. I think we can all agree that is true. And at some point there will be a "SPAC attack" as people like to call it. We saw it mid-September and it took until Nov. to fully recover in many cases. 

How do you quantify the risk of being in positions you cannot get out of when the bubble pops? How do you quantify the lost opportunity of buying SPACs at a discount in the middle of one of those attacks?

Most of my biggest gains in November are the result of having cash on the sidelines that I put to use during the September attack. I just booked a 103% gain on my SPAC holdings due mostly to paying less "opportunity cost" in Sept. than a "zero risk" parking money in near-NAV strategy would have paid. I could follow a "park til pop" strategy for the next 12 months and come no where near my November gains even AFTER excluding the "average" SPAC gains. All due to rejecting the "zero risk" thesis.

But of course the bottom line is to follow a strategy that you understand, are comfortable with, and that seems to work for you based on your risk profile.

author: bwayne11111
body:
Work is increasing because a take over price will be greater than the current market price. (Probably pretty close now after the run up last week)

CRM is decreasing because they will likely use stock to purchase work. This means CRM will print stock like money and inflation will occur. The market cap of CRM will increase (from stock being printed to acquire work) but the overall value will not increase. In other words, dilution of shares will take place. This future devaluing of the company stock is causing people to sell off some shares

Hello!  
30 y/o, started out trading stocks around 5 months ago. Invested 100-300 euros every month. Learned a lot and gonna learn lots more! I use Revolut app for this, so I am a bit limited to what I can trade, but it seems enough for now.

Currently, I have:  
AAL 20,5 shares  
AAPL 1,72 shares  
CCL 3 shares  
NFLX 0,41 shares  
PLTR 7,58 shares  
PFE 2,98 shares  
TSLA 0,94 shares  
VTRS 6,91 shares  
XPEV 3,49 shares.

Played a little with NIO and SFIX, MSFT, but since I am new to this and impatient, sold at (in my mind) good profit and bought other stuff, now it feels weird to buy back, let's say NIO. Currently, I calculate 27,4% profit on my portfolio from the cash I invested, so I consider myself lucky for not screwing up these savings too much. Usually I stay in the green, except for Netflix, Pfizer and Viatris, so maybe I'll get rid of these when the time feels right. I plan on continuing investing cash every month and learning more, comments are really welcome :)

author: LavenderAutist
body:
Well, I do understand convertibles and I understand the silly gambit that happened earlier this year.

Elon was in a tough position with the convertible debt and needed the share price to rise so that the debt could convert to equity and he would be able to get more cash to fund their operations.

If the share price didn't skyrocket this year, Tesla would be in a whole different situation.

If I were Elon, I would try to do a $25 billion share offering. It would be 5% of thier current valuation. And if the share price fell, no big deal. They would have enough cash to go hard at their new business lines without worrying about where to get it in the future.

The counter argument would be that the dollar is losing its value so why do so much now. But it is also my opinion that many experts who believe in this reflation trade and the death of the dollar are wrong. So my assumptions drive my options.

author: gurglemonster
body:
Because it isn't. There were some failed platforms (BitLending I think) but the only time crypto is lent out an interest payed is where it's the borrowed funds in a speculative bet by another party, in the case of Bitcoin always on a centralized exchange. 

No rational individual borrows in crypto because it's like exposing themselves to the most insane currency risk ever. Literally 3 days ago you could buy a Bitcoin for 16,800 USD, now it's nearly 20,000. If you had traded that Bitcoin for services rendered for fiat, you'd have to find 20,000 to replace the borrowed Bitcoin, excluding any interest charges. 

There is a reason that 10 years after Bitcoins inception, its market is still made of up almost entirely of speculation, those in the market for illegal goods and services and the outright insane that believe the world will end but somehow the internet and their Bitcoin / crypto will remain unaffected.
